Award.AwardTitle: OPUS: Coupling of Carbon, Nitrogen, Silica and Phosphorus Cycles in Coastal Ecosystems: Climate Effects and Trophic Implications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Located at the interface between land, atmosphere and ocean, estuaries are shaped by their physical properties and the surrounding landscape. These dynamic coastal systems respond to changes in climate and human actions over years and decades. Many estuaries receive large inputs of nutrients from adjacent ecosystems that fuels the high productivity of both plants and animals. Estuaries are also sites of intense cycling (re-use) of key elements like carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus and silica. This project uses the Chesapeake Bay region to investigate how elemental cycles maybe synchronized over regions and seasons, how linkages between different element cycles are affected by estuary shape, climate and increased nutrients, and how living resources, such as zooplankton and shellfish, respond to changes in element cycles. These processes will be evaluated in linked estuarine networks using a large monitoring database and simple computational models. Comparisons among subregions, such as different river tributaries, will generate a broader knowledge about estuaries in general.

Society will benefit from a deeper understanding of how different regions and element cycles of complex estuaries, such as the Chesapeake Bay, are linked and respond to change because this new knowledge will inform watershed management plans. This work will advance knowledge of how climate modifies living resource and water quality responses to nutrient management. Project investigators will collaborate with Chesapeake Bay resource managers to analyze data and and interpret results, making the results immediately useful for developing nutrient waste management strategies that improve water quality and sustain living resources. This study will also stimulate development of a new graduate course that teaches the logic, importance and methods of synthesis research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Located at the interfaces between land, atmosphere and ocean, estuaries are shaped by their physical properties (size, depth, tidal range) and diverse external factors (river flows, adjacent land uses and other human activities). These dynamic coastal systems exhibit fluctuations and trends in response to changes in weather, climate and human forces over time scales of days to multiple decades.  Many estuaries receive large inputs of nutrients (N, nitrogen; P, phosphorus; Si, Silica) and various forms of organic matter (C, organic carbon as biomass and food material for estuarine plants and animals) from the adjacent watershed, atmosphere and coastal ocean, fueling high productivity of both plants and animals and intense cycling (re-use) of key elements like C, N, P and Si. This project used Chesapeake Bay and its tributary estuaries as sites to investigate (1) how well elemental cycles are synchronized over regions and seasons, (2) how linkages between cycles are affected by estuary size/shape, climatic factors and nutrient additions, and (3) how estuarine water quality and living resources respond to changes in these linkages and additions. Measured ecological processes will be expanded to ecosystem-level networks using a large monitoring data base and simple computational models. Comparative synthesis among tributaries will generate a broader knowledge about estuaries in general.

            Analyses have provided expanded understanding of links between physics, chemistry and ecology, and results have advanced knowledge of how both weather and climate modulate estuarine ecosystem responses to nutrient management. Here we highlight the most compelling and insightful outcomes of this project, which have implications for our fundamental understanding of estuaries and also for how we expect these systems to change in the future.  First, modest nutrient load reductions to the estuary in recent decades have resulted in decreased indices of eutrophication, including reduced levels of low-oxygen conditions (hypoxia) and reduced existence of no-oxygen conditions (anoxia) in deep water across time and space. In fact, anoxic conditions have disappeared entirely in some recent years. Secondly, deep water N concentrations have progressively decreased while at the same time deep water oxygen concentrations have increased in previously oxygen-deprived regions, strongly suggesting that excess N is being removed via microbial processes (e.g. nitrification) that had previously been underestimated. Consequently, these linked processes should lead to suppressed summer algal blooms due to nutrient limitation, allowing water quality to likely improve. Third, in using a relatively long-term water quality data set, we were able to highlight that estuarine responses to changes in factors such as river flow, nutrient loads and weather conditions are surprisingly fast, many on time scales of several years and some even faster. This finding contradicts traditional perspectives that estuaries and other aquatic ecosystems require relatively long periods to recover from eutrophication.  Fourth, an examination of water quality data from a variety of Chesapeake Bay tributaries (comparative analysis) indicated that both physical features (e.g., depth, strength of water column stratification) and external nutrient loading rates played strong roles in determining water quality conditions, such as oxygen depletion and the accumulation of chlorophyll-a. Finally, a global review of estuarine sediment processes (oxygen consumption and nutrient recycling) indicated that sediments serve an important, and sometimes dominating, role in nutrient and oxygen cycling within these productive ecosystems.

Project investigators have and will continue to collaborate with Chesapeake Bay resource managers to focus analyses and interpret results, making them more useful for forming nutrient waste management strategies that improve water quality and sustain living estuarine resources. This study also stimulated development of a new graduate course that teaches the logic, importance and methods of synthesis research, with special emphasis on simulation modeling of estuarine issues.
